urlLink Apparently Size Does Matter to PS3 PS3 discs will dwarf current DVDs capacity. August 04, 2004 - Sony announced today that their next generation console, the PlayStation 3, will utilize the Blu-Ray disc format which blows apart the current DVD system's capabilities. The Blu-Ray discs will be able to hold up to 5 times as much data. Blu-Ray discs are similar to DVDs except they use blue laser light as opposed to red laser light to read and write data. The PlayStation 3 will come equipped with the Blu-Ray technology allowing playback of high definition movies (which are expected to change to the new format in the coming years). The storage capacity of the Blu-Ray discs dwarf the amount stored on DVDs. So much so, that they don't have to spell Blue with an 'e'. A single-layer Blu-Ray disc can hold up to 27Gb on a single layer as opposed to 4.7Gb on a DVD. No worries, though, if you use your PS2 to watch movies. The Blu-Ray technology allows it to read original DVD discs. Other units that feature the read-only standard will start to appear near the end of the current fiscal year through March 2005. During that same span, Sony plans on revealing the PlayStation 3. Juicy, juicy.
